articles.headline: JPMorgan May Face New Scrutiny in China Hiring Case
articles.snippet: The bank’s top regulators are seeking to impose their own penalties in the China hiring case, according to people briefed on the investigations.
articles.abstract: The bank’s top regulators are seeking to impose their own penalties in the China hiring case, according to people briefed on the investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last three years, JPMorgan Chase’s hiring practices in China were at the center of a federal bribery investigation.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Wells Fargo Tests Justice Department’s Get-Tough Approach
articles.snippet: Guidelines issued last year by the Justice Department stressed the need to hold individuals accountable for corporate misdeeds.
articles.abstract: Guidelines issued last year by the Justice Department stressed the need to hold individuals accountable for corporate misdeeds.
articles.lead_paragraph: In response to widespread public criticism that the government has been too lenient with executives responsible for corporate crime, Deputy Attorney General Sally Quillian Yates issued tough new guidelines last year for federal prosecutors.

articles.headline: Fatal Shooting by Police Shakes Charlotte’s Self-Image
articles.snippet: After decades in which it willed itself to big-city status, Charlotte, in the last decade, has had to grapple with a host of big-city problems.
articles.abstract: After decades in which it willed itself to big-city status, Charlotte, in the last decade, has had to grapple with a host of big-city problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE — This has always been a place that has prided itself on order, consensus and a can-do corporate mentality that turned a locale with no real geographic reason to exist into one of the hemisphere’s financial dynamos.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Crime Policies Might Hit Minorities Harder, Experts Say
articles.snippet: Civil rights activists and national security veterans fear Mr. Trump’s plan could have the effect of treating minorities with suspicion and singling them out for scrutiny.
articles.abstract: Civil rights activists and national security veterans fear Mr. Trump’s plan could have the effect of treating minorities with suspicion and singling them out for scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: Branding himself the “law-and-order candidate,” Donald J. Trump has vowed to carry out a crackdown on crime and terrorism that would benefit white Americans and racial minorities alike.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Farah Stockman

articles.headline: Audiobooks Turn More Readers Into Listeners as E-Books Slip
articles.snippet: Publishers saw their revenue dip early this year compared with 2015, in part because they lacked a runaway hit and the sales of e-books fell sharply.
articles.abstract: Publishers saw their revenue dip early this year compared with 2015, in part because they lacked a runaway hit and the sales of e-books fell sharply.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sales of paperback books are up. Independent bookstores are thriving again. The threat of a digital apocalypse has subsided, as e-book sales have tumbled.
